header.title: Queen Mother’s teeth: Why were they so bad? Why didn’t she see a dentist? Dentist explains
header.subtitle: THE QUEEN MOTHER is one of the most famous Queen’s in British history, after she stood by her husband’s side during his unexpected and difficult rise to the throne.
header.postText: 'The Queen Mother was known as the Smiling Duchess, due to her strong character. However, her smiles have caused some to comment on her discoloured teeth in later life. So, why did they look this way?', 'Matthew Rose, from the Restorative Dentist The Implant Centre Hove & Hayward’s Heath, explained all to Express.co.uk.', 'He said: The Queen Mother was born in 1900, so in an era where dentistry, as we know it today, was completely different.', 'Dentistry was more invasive as mainly comprised of extractions if a tooth presented with a problem, and the preventative side we are all familiar with now such as fluoride, was not known about.', 'Modern cosmetic dentistry with its bright white smiles was simply not available to The Queen Mother for the majority of her life.', 'The Queen Mother could have opted for dental work later in life, but it appears she didn’t care to have any tweaks.', 'Matthew added: So even though an aesthetically pleasing smile might have been available as an option to her when she became older, perhaps this was something that was just not important to her.', 'Matthew also revealed how Prince William had subtle cosmetic dentistry after a losing tooth at a friend’s wedding.', 'He said: Post 2014 when it was rumoured that he lost a tooth, the upper right central incisor (UR1) looks lighter, and more aligned - as do the upper lateral incisors.', 'It looks to me as if these teeth have been either crowned or veneered.', 'Dentists have claimed Kate Middleton’s imperfect teeth always in demand, unlike Meghan’s perfect Hollywood smile. /life-style/life/1148060/kate-middleton-meghan-markle-latest-news-teeth.', 'Matthew revealed: Kate Middleton’s teeth are what we would call practically imperfect, perfect teeth.', 'They are straight but not perfectly aligned, they are a good size and shape although the proportion of length to width looks slightly out.', 'Meghan Markle, on the other hand, has a whiter smile, the dental expert claims.', 'Matt said: We have seen some requests for the Meghan Markle smile which is whiter, more American and stand out but far less natural looking than Kate’s.', 'Meghan’s teeth look a little unnatural, she has possibly recently had orthodontics (brace) and lots of of bleaching.', 'Sometimes in post ortho cases teeth can look at little ‘splayed’ and along with the rounded incisal edges that she has, they just don’t look as natural as Kate’s. Kate’s smile is more likely to be the one that will always be in demand.', 'Queen Elizabeth 's mother was a queen as she was married to the king, the Queen’s father.', ' He was King George VI, who was actually the second born son in his family, and never meant to rule.', ' However, his brother was forced to abdicate the throne so he could marry the love of his life, who happened to be divorced - something forbidden by the government at the time.', ' So, the Queen Mother became Queen Elizabeth when her husband became Queen. ', ' She was technically Queen consort, the tile of a Queen by marriage. However, she was known as Queen Elizabeth. ', ' She later became known as Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother to avoid confusion.'

commentThread.commentText: Obviously the author has no idea what dentistry was like in those days. My school dentist used a pedal drill like those used on old sewing machines and a 2 - 3 mm needle for aneasthetics. All very different from today's ultrasonic drills and 0,2mm syringes.

replies.commentText: Many Thanks from all the readers in the world.  If it weren't for you, we'd already know.
What in the early 60,s till she deceased. Rubbish
Yes, your comment is indeed rubbish.!

Visit every 3 months as a child. Multiple 3-4 fillings a visit so by the time you got to your teens they were not in great shape. Not that the were needed but it was "payment by drill" in those days on the NHS. Fortunately got 6 caps in the late 1980's but they are shot now. Implants in a few years. My daughters both in their mid 30's have never had a filling!

commentThread.commentText: Does the "journalist" know something about the Queen's father that we don't? She wrote, "So the Queen Mother became Queen Elizabeth when her husband became Queen". I think you will find he became KING.

replies.commentText: It is all that new gender identity stuff that is going on these days.
Give it time with this new lot.

commentThread.commentText: The Queen Mother died in March 2002, a rather odd thing to do to write an article about a womans teeth who has been dead for nearly 18 years now ... slow news day ???

commentThread.commentText: She probably did ... back then it was drill and fill to make a living.

commentThread.commentText: What a load of ill informed tosh.
The Queen will be rooting for Corbyn to get in and get her teeth done for nowt.

replies.commentText: Leave the queen alone. Nothing wrong with her teeth.

commentThread.commentText: I met the queen mother in 1960, and her teeth were rotten then. I never got over it. Nothing wrong with dentistry then....

replies.commentText: P.S  or since.
You are joking! Dentistry was truly awful. Payment by drill and fill! No fluoride in water or toothpaste. Foot pedal drills.

Not so in the 60's.  I was a young adult then and remember well how much better dentistry was.  Fluoridisation began in the 60's too.   Slow, foot pedal drills were a thing of the past by the early 60's. I know this because I worked in dentistry in a cotton town in Lancashire.
Well they were certainly around in the late 50's and the first high speed drill I ever experienced was in 1987 in Crewe. Not every NHS dentist upgraded, our's in Alsager certainly never did.
Not joking luv, I had just had a child, in 1959 so my teeth were important to me.  So nothing wrong with dentistry then, or since.....

replies.commentText: Yes but media presentable US Americans have very expensive but false teeth, ie not of their natural ownership, not many people are born or grow up with perfectly straight white teeth do they. Was in the US recently and noticed in New York that only the 'nicest' upper class people had these perfect teeth and working class people of different ethnic backgrounds did not on account that they could not aford the insane dental fees.
Anyone can have good teeth if they look after them. Whether or not they are perfectly aligned etc doesn 't matter to most people.

America, for that's where I assume you come from, must be a land of perfect teeth and perfect bodies - IF you can afford them! Most of the perfect bodies and probably teeth, too are rather artificial.Bit of plastic here, nip and tuck there, some liposuction elsewhere, loads of whitening in the mouth. Sure, we can all be body - perfect at a price, can 't we Nicomore?
Look again at amygdalus's flag.  It is not USA!

Im not from America, try again, but where I am from dental hygiene is regarded and we don't walk around looking like are teeth came from the middle ages, brown and yellow and disgusting. Ppl who are known for bad teeth shouldnt be knocking a nation who make sure theres look pleasant, and lets not try to act like your country doesnt do lipo, nip and tucks all though from the looks of it very bad ones/ Fergies face was lifted, she should sue the dr.

C'mon, nothing is REAL in your part of the world; chest, nose, teeth, lips, eyes, news, face, personality, etc..  you name it.  'Plastic fantastic'..  If they could stretch people vertically at present for a hefty sum, they'd do it too, over there.

That coming from a Brit is a compliment. That means her teeth look healthy.
So you have extensive knowledge of every British person's teeth? And MM's million megawatt grin is as false as her bleached-to-infinity teeth.

Did I say every British person. And I will take Meghan's bleached infinity teeth than the disgusting pieces of butter like teeth that I've seen on the ppl over there, talk about yuck mouth, and the things is the Brits are known for bad teeth and have the audacity to try to argue with ppl over it. They just need to stay out of the conversation of dentistry, Thats like italians trying to talk about curry.
